SubTopics: Develop a model to describe the movement of matter among producers, consumers, decomposers, and the air, water, and soil in the environment to (a) show that plants produce sugars and plant materials, (b) show that animals can eat plants and/or other animals for food, and (c) show that some organisms, including fungi and bacteria, break down dead organisms and recycle some materials back to the air and soil.
Content: A desert food web is shown.
problems/MA23G5S/media/1a.jpg
Which of the following would most likely happen if the rattlesnakes were removed from the ecosystem?

B.Choice: Barrel cactus would be eaten by hawks.

C.Choice: Squirrels would not have a food source.

D.Choice: Hawks would eat more squirrels and mice.

SubTopics: Describe and graph the relative amounts of salt water in the ocean; fresh water in lakes, rivers, and groundwater; and fresh water frozen in glaciers and polar ice caps to provide evidence about the availability of fresh water in Earth's biosphere.
Content: The circle graph shows where fresh water is found on Earth.
problems/MA23G5S/media/2a.jpg
Which of the following best explains why only a small percentage of the fresh water on Earth is available for human use?

A.Choice: Most fresh water is stored deep underground.

B.Choice: Most fresh water is frozen in glaciers and ice caps.

C.Choice: Most fresh water is trapped in the air as water vapor.

D.Choice: Most fresh water is found in lakes in areas that are hard to reach.

SubTopics: Obtain information to describe that energy and fuels humans use are derived from natural resources and that some energy and fuel sources are renewable and some are not.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
A house is currently powered by electricity from a coal-burning power plant. The owner wants to add solar panels and a small wind turbine to generate electricity for the house.
The energy resource that produces the electricity the house currently uses is a

B.Choice: renewable resource.

Content: Which of the following describes sunlight and wind?

A.Choice: Sunlight and wind are both renewable resources.

B.Choice: Sunlight and wind are both nonrenewable resources.

C.Choice: Sunlight is a renewable resource and wind is a nonrenewable resource.

D.Choice: Sunlight is a nonrenewable resource and wind is a renewable resource.

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret maps of Earth's mountain ranges, deep ocean trenches, volcanoes, and earthquake epicenters to describe patterns of these features and their locations relative to boundaries between continents and oceans.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
The map shows three locations labeled X, Y, and Z.
problems/MA23G5S/media/4a.jpg
Which location is more likely to experience earthquakes and volcanoes?

B.Choice: location Y

Content: This location is more likely to experience earthquakes and volcanoes because it is

B.Choice: in the middle of the ocean.

C.Choice: in the middle of a continent.

SubTopics: Gather information using various informational resources on possible solutions to a design problem. Present different representations of a design solution.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗛𝗥𝗘𝗘 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.

Two students designed a game that involves throwing balls into holes in a box to earn points. The students drew two diagrams to represent the game design, as shown. One of the balls from the game is also shown in each diagram.
problems/MA23G5S/media/5a.jpg
problems/MA23G5S/media/5b.jpg
The students will build a prototype of the game.
Identify the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 diagram for the students to use to build the prototype. Explain why the students should use this diagram.

B.Choice: Diagram 2

Content: The students tested the prototype and realized they had made a mistake in their design. Players were supposed to be able to earn 10, 50, or 100 points with a single throw of the ball, but this was not possible.
Describe one change to the game design that could be made to correct this mistake. Be sure to use specific details of the change to the design in your answer.

After the students corrected the mistake, they decided to test the game. The students placed the prototype on a table and played the game. They found that balls that did not go through the holes fell on the floor during the game.
Describe one change to the prototype that would stop balls from falling on the floor.

SubTopics: Apply scientific principles of energy and motion to test and refine a device that converts kinetic energy to electrical energy or uses stored energy to cause motion or produce light or sound.
Content: A student builds a toy car like the one shown in the diagram. The student turns the propeller, which twists the elastic band. When the student releases the car on a flat surface, the propeller spins and the car moves forward.
problems/MA23G5S/media/6a.jpg
Which of the following changes could be made to test how the amount of stored energy affects the distance the car travels?

B.Choice: release the car on different surfaces

C.Choice: place objects of different masses on the car

D.Choice: turn the propeller different numbers of times

SubTopics: Ask testable questions about the process by which plants use air, water, and energy from sunlight to produce sugars and plant materials needed for growth and reproduction.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.

A student investigated the growth of bean plants under different conditions. She had ten bean plants, each in an identical pot, with the same amount of soil in each pot. The student measured the height of each plant. Then she separated the plants into two groups of five plants each. The student placed one group in a dark room and the other group in an area that had light. She gave each plant the same amount of water twice a week. After four weeks, the student measured the height of each plant again.
Explain why the student measured the height of each plant before she separated the plants into two groups.
Identify which group of plants most likely grew more in height over the four weeks. Explain your reasoning. In your explanation, be sure to include the process that plants use to help them grow.

B.Choice: Plants in area with light

SubTopics: Define a simple design problem that reflects a need or a want. Include criteria for success and constraints on materials, time, or cost that a potential solution must meet.
Content: A class wants to build the structure shown for an outdoor garden at school.
problems/MA23G5S/media/8a.jpg
Which of the following problems would 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 be solved by building this structure?

B.Choice: water draining from soil too quickly

C.Choice: soil eroding when sprayed with a hose

D.Choice: plants turning brown from too much sunlight

SubTopics: Evaluate the merit of a design solution that reduces the damage caused by weather.
Content: A town is planning to build a seawall to protect beach property from erosion caused by ocean waves. An example of a seawall is shown.
problems/MA23G5S/media/9a.jpg
Which of the following is the most important factor to consider when choosing the best design solution for the seawall?

A.Choice: the temperature of the ocean water

B.Choice: the height of the highest ocean waves

C.Choice: the number of plants on the beach property

D.Choice: the types of buildings on the beach property

SubTopics: Provide evidence, including through the analysis of data, that plants and animals have traits inherited from parents and that variation of these traits exist in a group of similar organisms.
Content: A scientist is studying a plant species with different-sized flowers. The scientist separates the plants into three groups for breeding. One group has plants with large flowers, one has plants with small flowers, and one has plants with both large and small flowers.
The scientist breeds plants that have similar-sized flowers with each other. The results from the breedings are shown in the table.
problems/MA23G5S/media/10a.jpg
Based on this information, what can be concluded about flower size in this plant species?

B.Choice: Flower size is an inherited trait.

C.Choice: Flower size always changes as the plants grow.

D.Choice: Flower size is determined only by the environment.

SubTopics: Use evidence to construct an explanation for how the variations in characteristics among individuals within the same species may provide advantages to these individuals in their survival and reproduction.
Content: A type of moth is active at night and rests on dark-colored tree trunks during the day. These moths can be black or mostly white. The diagram shows two of the moths on a tree trunk.
problems/MA23G5S/media/11a.jpg

A population of birds moves into the area where the moths live, and the birds begin to eat the moths. Which of the following best describes the moth population many generations after the birds move into the area?

A.Choice: The population will have the same number of black moths and white moths because color is an inherited trait.

B.Choice: The population will have fewer black moths than white moths because the black moths blend in with the environment.

C.Choice: The population will have more black moths than white moths because the white moths are more easily seen by predators.

D.Choice: The population will have the same number of black moths and white moths because they are always born in equal numbers.

SubTopics: Use a particle model of matter to explain common phenomena involving gases, and phase changes between gas and liquid and between liquid and solid.
Content: Which of the following best shows the water particles at different times during the investigations?

B.Choice: problems/MA23G5S/media/12b.jpg

SubTopics: Use a particle model of matter to explain common phenomena involving gases, and phase changes between gas and liquid and between liquid and solid.
Content: During investigation 1, the ice in the beaker changed phase between 10:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m.
Which of the following best describes the change to the ice in the beaker?

A.Choice: The ice condensed into water because the ice gained heat energy.

B.Choice: The ice evaporated into water because the ice lost heat energy.

C.Choice: The ice melted into water because the ice gained heat energy.

D.Choice: The ice melted into water because the ice lost heat energy.

SubTopics: Make observations and measurements of substances to describe characteristic properties of each, including color, hardness, reflectivity, electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity, response to magnetic forces, and solubility.
Content: The students conducted a third investigation. They had two unlabeled substances in containers. They knew that one substance was salt and the other was white sand.
The students completed the following steps:

:ibox:• Observe whether each substance takes the shape of its container.

• Measure the masses and volumes of the unlabeled substances.

• Mix each substance in water and observe whether the substance dissolves.
Which of the following would most help determine which substance was salt and which was white sand?

A.Choice: measuring the mass of each substance

B.Choice: measuring the volume of each substance

C.Choice: observing whether each substance dissolves in water

D.Choice: observing whether each substance takes the shape of its container

SubTopics: Measure and graph the weights (masses) of substances before and after a reaction or phase change to provide evidence that regardless of the type of change that occurs when heating, cooling, or combining substances, the total weight (mass) of matter is conserved.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
The data from investigation 2 show the mass of the beaker and its contents.
Explain why the mass of the contents in the beaker decreased during the investigation.
The students repeated investigation 2 with the same amounts of salt and water, but this time they put a lid on top of the beaker, as shown.
problems/MA23G5S/media/15a.jpg
The mass of the beaker, the lid, and the beaker's contents was 90 g on day 1. The students continued to measure the mass of the setup for three days.
What was the most likely total mass, in grams, of the beaker, the lid, and the beaker's contents on day 3 of the investigation? Explain your reasoning.

SubTopics: Generate several possible solutions to a given design problem. Compare each solution based on how well each is likely to meet the criteria and constraints of the design problem.
Content: Solar cookers use sunlight to cook food. A student designs two solar cookers, as shown.
problems/MA23G5S/media/16a.jpg
problems/MA23G5S/media/16b.jpg
Design 1 is a cardboard box with a lid that has a window made of hard, clear plastic. The lid can be removed from the box.

Design 2 is a wooden box with a lid that has a window made of clear plastic wrap. The lid can be lifted but not removed from the box. A sheet of aluminum foil that reflects light covers the bottom of the box.
The student tests both designs and finds that food cooks faster in one of the designs.
Which of the following best explains why one design cooks food faster than the other?

A.Choice: Design 1 cooks faster because the box is made of cardboard, not wood.

B.Choice: Design 2 cooks faster because the lid can be lifted and does not need to be removed.

C.Choice: Design 2 cooks faster because its aluminum foil reflects sunlight, and cardboard does not.

D.Choice: Design 1 cooks faster because sunlight passes through hard plastic more easily than clear plastic wrap.

SubTopics: Use graphs and tables of local weather data to describe and predict typical weather during a particular season in an area.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Part of a weather forecast for four days is shown in the table.
problems/MA23G5S/media/17a.jpg
Based on the data in the table, on which day is it most likely to snow?

B.Choice: day 2

Content: Which of the following describes the weather on day 4 compared to the other days?

A.Choice: Day 4 has the coldest temperature and the windiest conditions.

B.Choice: Day 4 has the warmest temperature and the windiest conditions.

C.Choice: Day 4 has the coldest temperature and is the least likely to have rain.

D.Choice: Day 4 has the warmest temperature and is the least likely to have rain.

SubTopics: Test a simple system designed to filter particulates out of water and propose one change to the design to improve it.
Content: Students tested a simple filter designed to remove particulates from water. The filter has a layer of cotton on top of layers of sand and gravel held in by a screen. The diagram shows the filter.
problems/MA23G5S/media/18a.jpg
The students found particulates in the water that had moved through the filter. Which of the following changes will most improve the filter?

A.Choice: removing the cotton above the sand

B.Choice: adding a coffee filter just above the screen

C.Choice: making the filter larger so it can hold more water

D.Choice: reducing the amount of water to be cleaned by the filter

SubTopics: Obtain and summarize information about the climate of different regions of the world to illustrate that typical weather conditions over a year vary by region.
Content: Australia has regions, such as deserts and rain forests, with very different climates. Which of the following data about each region would be most helpful for learning about the different climates?

A.Choice: daily wind direction and daily wind speed data over one year

B.Choice: number of major floods and fires over one summer and one fall

C.Choice: sunrise and sunset times for winter and summer over several years

D.Choice: average seasonal precipitation and average temperatures over several years

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret given data about changes in a habitat and describe how the changes may affect the ability of organisms that live in that habitat to survive and reproduce.
Content: Which of the following is an example of an organism responding to the seasonal changes of less sunlight and colder temperatures?

B.Choice: birds starting to build a nest

C.Choice: trees starting to lose their leaves
